article_title: The two casualties of blocking Merrick Garland
article_text:
01:16 Lake Norman coal ash Pause

00:54 People flock to Speed Street

00:46 ShopTalk Video: Women's Business Center-Charlotte

01:39 Fashion designer Charles Harbison and HB2

01:11 Southern Grace Distillieries plans to move into an old prison

00:42 Father yells at Union County school bus driver

01:24 Benny Parsons will not be forgotten

article_metadata.news-keywords: Garland Merrick, Supreme Court nominee, John Wester, McConnell
article_metadata.description: Thus far, the nomination of Judge Merrick Garland to the U.S. Supreme Court has hit a “nothing doing” from Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell – a position he advanced within hours of the death of Justice Antonin Scalia. Sen. McConnell, and his colleague Sen. Charles Grassley, chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, have maintained that the Senate should not consider – much less confirm – a replacement for Justice Antonin Scalia until after the next election. Doing so will, Grassley says, “defer to the American people,” and, according to McConnell, follow a “long-standing tradition of not filling vacancies on the Supreme Court in the middle of a presidential election year.”
article_metadata.title: The two casualties of blocking Merrick Garland | The Charlotte Observer

Sen. McConnell, and his colleague Sen. Charles Grassley, chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, have maintained that the Senate should not consider – much less confirm – a replacement for Justice Antonin Scalia until after the next election. Doing so will, Grassley says, “defer to the American people,” and, according to McConnell, follow a “long-standing tradition of not filling vacancies on the Supreme Court in the middle of a presidential election year.”
